standfirst:
• Eric Garner died on Thursday after confrontation
• Medics' restrictions in effect pending investigation
headline: Four emergency workers on 'modified duty' over NYPD chokehold death

standfirst: Paris jail known for brutal conditions, which once housed Carlos the Jackal, Jean Genet and Jacques Mesrine, to reopen in 2019
headline: France's notorious La Santé prison receives four-year renovation term

standfirst:
Ten historians from 10 countries give a brief history of the first world war through a global lens. Using original news reports, interactive maps and rarely-seen footage, including extraordinary scenes of troops crossing Mesopotamia on camels and Italian soldiers fighting high up in the Alps, the half-hour film explores the war and its effects from many different perspectives. You can watch the documentary in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Arabic or Hindi thanks to our partnership with the British Academy.

Warning: contains images some viewers may find disturbing
headline: A global guide to the first world war - interactive documentary

standfirst: With three major plane crashes in a week, it seems air disasters are happening very frequently at present – but, statistically, how common are such crashes?
headline: How common are plane crashes?

standfirst: Alex Kozinski says 'enterprise is flawed' and that America should return to the firing squad because current system is so ineffective
headline: Top judge attacks lethal injection as Arizona fails in death penalty appeal

Repblican senator John McCain describes botched execution as 'torture' as controversy intensifies about death penalty drug secrecy

standfirst: Two-day event organised by Human Rights Foundation aims to find new ways to spread information inside North Korea. North Korea Tech reports
headline: Silicon Valley to host North Korea 'hackathon'

standfirst: Tom Watson and David Davis apply for judicial review of 'emergency' legislation, which was rushed through parliament
headline: Drip surveillance law faces legal challenge by MPs

standfirst:
Palmer united party senator Jaqcui Lambie has told a Tasmanian radio station that the right man for her must be 'well-hung' and have a package between the legs.
The Heart 107.3 hosts asked Lambie if they could help 'find her love' on their Hobart show , with the senator answering by telling them 'they must have heaps of cash and they've got to have a package between the legs.' 'You might not be able to handle Jacqui Lambie', the senator tells a caller to the show.
headline: Palmer united senator Jacqui Lambie tells radio station her perfect man must be well-hung – video

standfirst: Swedish filmmaker taps into the primary violence of the coloniser rather than the colonised, says Bhakti Shringarpure
headline: Fanon documentary confronts fallacies about anti-colonial philosopher

standfirst: Abbey choir commissions David Matthews, whose grandfather died weeks before armistice
headline: Haunting 1914 poem inspires composer of Westminster Abbey's war vigil anthem

standfirst: The Australian model, DJ and television personality opens up about her struggle with gender identity depicted in her new video
headline: Ruby Rose: 'I used to pray to God that I wouldn’t get breasts'

standfirst: Siraj was sentenced to 30 years in prison in 2007 for conspiring to plant bombs in New York City. The way he got there is similar to a spate of US 'stings' to capture terror suspects since 9/11
headline: Shahawar Matin Siraj: 'impressionable' young man caught in an NYPD sting

standfirst: The US Alliance for Bangladeshi Worker Safety has issued its first annual report on factory safety in Bangladesh

standfirst: Health secretary intervenes after Guardian investigation reveals strict hygiene standards can be disregarded in practice

standfirst: Grand infrastructure projects would turn the east coast city of Wonsan into a modern tourist haven – if they get off the ground. NK News reports

standfirst: From dog meat soup to boiled rabbit, Pyongyang recommends eating a 'revitalising' diet to survive the hottest days of the year. Daily NK reports
headline: How to survive a heatwave, North Korea style

standfirst: Oresharski's one-year tenure overshadowed by protests against corruption, deadly floods and disputes over gas pipeline project
headline: Bulgaria's prime minister Plamen Oresharski resigns

standfirst: Attorney files motion to dismiss lawsuit in state which is the last to face a challenge to ban on gay marriage
headline: Lawyer calls for North Dakota decision on same-sex marriage ban

standfirst: Angry scenes in Indian parliament over footage of Rajan Baburao Vichare trying to push chapati into fasting man's mouth

• Human Rights Watch documents 'sting' operations
• Report raises questions about post-9/11 civil rights

headline: US warned: surveillance reform hinges on change to Reagan executive order

standfirst: Hawaiian photographer Clark Little gets to the heart of the action and shoots ocean waves in Oahu as they roll over him
headline: Hawaii's spectacular ocean waves – in pictures

standfirst: On 13 January 2012, the Costa Concordia ran aground on the island of Giglio in Italy, in a tragedy that caused the loss of 32 lives. As the ship is towed away on its final journey to a shipbreaker in Genoa today, we look back over the events of the last two-and-a-half years
headline: Costa Concordia - in pictures

standfirst: He's a self-made man who has climbed to the top job in the world's largest presidential democracy. But how much do you really know about this furniture-building Metallica fan? Known as 'Jokowi', the governor of Jakarta, Joko Widodo, has taken home 53% of the vote and will be Indonesia's next president
headline: Ten things to know about Indonesia’s new president, Joko Widodo – video

standfirst: Officials give conflicting details about when Air Algérie plane went missing with 116 on board, as three-country search begins
headline: Air Algérie flight AH5017‬ disappears from radar in sandstorm

standfirst: The wreckage of the cruise ship Costa Concordia leaves the Italian port of Giglio on Wednesday where it sank two and a half years ago, killing 32 people. The ship has been re-floated and is being towed to Genoa, where it will be broken up and used for scrap
headline: Costa Concordia begins final voyage as it is towed from crash site – video report

standfirst:
• Theodore Wafer shot dead unarmed woman
• Case attracts concern over race issues
headline: Renisha McBride shooting trial set to begin in Detroit

standfirst: Distraught parents cling to hope, 100 days after Islamist rebels kidnapped nearly 300 of their daughters from a school in Borno state
headline: Families of abducted girls fight Boko Haram – and a supine government

standfirst: Ruling Communist party says firm belief in Marxism will help keep country's clamour for western-style democracy at bay

standfirst: Airliner comes down in north Africa with 116 on board, including 51 French, after departing Burkina Faso for Algiers
headline: Air Algérie AH5017 crash brings week's airliner death toll to 450

standfirst: Aids 2014 symposium in Melbourne hears drug combination known as PaMZ can treat drug-resistant TB in as little as four months
headline: New drug therapy allows tuberculosis and HIV to be treated simultaneously

standfirst: New report shows how police, sex workers and drugs users can work together to beat HIV
headline: Aids conference hears why Ghana police chief carries bag of condoms

standfirst: Experts blame economic and cultural changes for decline in weddings
headline: Marriage falls out of favour for young Europeans as austerity and apathy bite

standfirst: Former US president Bill Clinton has told delegates at a Melbourne Aids conference not to weaken their resolve following the downing of flight MH17 over Ukraine. At least six people on board were heading to the Aids 2014 conference in Melbourne. All 298 people on the Malaysia Airlines flight were killed
headline: MH17: Bill Clinton urges resolve at Aids conference in face of plane disaster  – video

standfirst: Yatseniuk quits as he berates parliament for failing to pass law to increase army financing and regulate country's energy situation
headline: Ukrainian prime minister Arseny Yatseniuk resigns

standfirst: Revolutionary UCLASS drone that can take off and land from aircraft carriers has been in development for nearly a decade
headline: Carrier-based drone offers way forward for US navy – subject to squabbling

standfirst: Long-withheld document provides insight into secretive system in which people can be placed on terrorism databases with astounding ease, and without any way to get off
headline: How the US's terrorism watchlists work – and how you could end up on one

standfirst: On eve of Girl Summit, ODI reveals trend of girls entering early marriages followed by swift divorces to migrate for family's sake
headline: Ethiopia's child brides see marriage as key to jobs abroad, says thinktank

standfirst: The Guardian's photo editors bring you a daily round up from the world of photography including the plane crash in Taiwan, the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow and a giant sunflower field in Japan
headline: Photo highlights of the day

standfirst: The French president confirms that the wreckage of flight AH5017 has been found in the Gossi area of Mali. François Hollande says none of the 118 people on board the plane survived, and says 51 of those were French nationals. The flight was announced missing when it did not arrive in Algiers at its scheduled time on Thursday
headline: Air Algérie crash: François Hollande offers condolences – video

standfirst: Whitehall review into freedom of movement lands blow to Eurosceptics aiming to make radical changes to migration rules
headline: EU report finds no evidence to support sweeping immigration reforms

standfirst: Gabriele Lauschet, who was 47, was a teacher at the German International School at Terrey Hills
headline: MH17: Sydney teacher identified as victim of Malaysia Airlines disaster

standfirst: The most heart wrenching part of parliament's condolence book ceremony was that the faces of the lost could so easily have been among the schoolchildren solemnly watching on
headline: MH17 tragedy reflected in the faces of schoolchildren at condolence ceremony

standfirst: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of Alexander Litvinenko, the former KGB spy poisoned with polonium in London in 2006, discusses a new inquiry into his death. She says the case could bring a "new era for relations between Russia and the west" – by revealing whether the Russian state supplied the radioactive material that killed her husband
headline: Litvinenko poisoning: inquiry could bring ‘new era for relations between Russia and the west’ says widow - video

standfirst: Meriam Ibrahim and her family meet Pope Francis on Thursday at the Vatican. Ibrahim, a Christian Sudanese woman, was spared the death sentence for apostasy in Sudan earlier this year. Ibrahim is married to a Christian US citizen and was sentenced to death for converting from Islam to Christianity
headline: Pope Francis meets Sudanese Christian woman spared death sentence for apostasy - video

standfirst: Tatyana Novikova says new Russian-funded nuclear plant bypassed planning rules and violates international conventions
headline: Belarus anti-nuclear activist fears for 'another Chernobyl' on her doorstep

standfirst: Prime minister has sent 50 police officers to London and is prepared to send them to Ukraine
headline: Australia has federal police ready to enter Ukraine and secure MH17 site

standfirst: Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, visits the construction site of a stadium in Samara being built for the 2018 World Cup. Speaking to a crowd of teenagers waving pom-poms he said the football championship would rival the success of the Sochi winter Olympics. Then he invited spectators to help him bury a time capsule containing a message promoting sport
headline: Vladimir Putin promotes Russia's 2018 World Cup - video

standfirst:
The pro-Russian separatists governing the part of eastern Ukraine above which flight MH17 is thought to have been downed by a missile have handed the black box flight recorders to Malaysian authorities. At a ceremony in the city of Donetsk, Malaysia expressed its 'sincere appreciation'

• Follow the latest developments in the global reaction to the downing of MH17 on our live blog
headline: MH17 black box handed to Malaysia by pro-Russian separatists – video

standfirst: Dignitaries watch as Dutch and Australian military transport planes bring bodies of the victims of the MH17 disaster to Eindhoven, the Netherlands, as the country holds a national day of mourning. Flight MH17 departed from Amsterdam's Schiphol airport before it was downed in eastern Ukraine. More than half of the 298 people killed were Dutch
headline: Bodies of MH17 victims arrive in the Netherlands on a day of mourning - video

standfirst: Video taken on Friday purports to show the black box recorder of flight MH17 being removed from its crash site in Ukraine, as cranes were used to remove part of the plane over the weekend. Rebel fighters say they have the black box and are prepared to hand it to international experts when they arrive in the town of Donetsk
headline: MH17: purported black box recorder being removed from crash site – video

standfirst: Military aircraft prepare to fly the first bodies retrieved from Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 to Eindhoven in the Netherlands. One hundred and ninety-three Dutch nationals were among the 298 people killed when the flight was shot down by pro-Russian rebels in Ukraine. Wednesday is a day of national mourning in the country
headline: MH17: relatives in the Netherlands await victims' bodies – video
Ukraine's 'hotheads'

standfirst:
• Embassy ends silence but refuses to reveal location
  • Attorney: 'US officials are mixed up in this detention'
headline: US diplomats admit contact in Yemen with missing citizen Sharif Mobley

standfirst: In a joint press conference the foreign ministers of the Netherlands and Australia announced that the Netherlands would take responsibility for the investigation into the crash of MH17. Australia's foreign minister, Julie Bishop, said the move would allow the investigation to begin 'in earnest'
headline: MH17: the Netherlands to take responsibility for crash investigation - video

standfirst: Many weapons and military components are still approved for export to Russia, report by four Commons committees says
headline: UK arms export licences for Russia still in place despite claims of embargo - report

standfirst: Pieter Broertjes called for 29-year-old to be expelled from the Netherlands in wake of plane disaster but later apologised
headline: MH17: Dutch mayor wants Vladimir Putin's daughter Maria deported

standfirst: The Australian prime minister, Tony Abbott, says trying to determine the number of bodies retrieved from the site of the MH17 crash has been difficult. Abbott says a number of factors including heat and interference from wildlife are hindering an already 'unprofessional' effort. He says his country will do its 'absolute utmost' to recover the bodies of any Australian victims
headline: Australia's Tony Abbott criticises search for MH17 bodies as 'unprofessional' – video

standfirst: Tony Abbott has branded the scene at the site of the MH17 disaster 'absolutely shambolic' and pushed for the repatriation of the 37 Australians killed. Abbott also said that in his most recent conversations with Vladimir Putin, the Russian president had 'said all the right things', 'but the challenge now is to hold the president to his word'
headline: Malaysia Airlines crash site 'absolutely shambolic', says Australian PM – video

standfirst: Malaysian officials receive flight recorders, while remains of 282 victims begin journey to Netherlands
headline: Ukraine rebels hand over MH17 black boxes and let train carrying bodies leave

standfirst: Move means special meeting of EU foreign ministers is unlikely to press ahead with generalised economic sanctions
headline: MH17 black box handover set to delay escalation of sanctions against Russia

standfirst: Alexander Khodakovsky reportedly told news agency rebels may have received Buk from Russia, then changes story
headline: MH17: Ukraine separatist commander 'admits' rebels had Buk missile system

standfirst: As Palestinians are granted a 12-hour ceasefire, people in Tehran, London, Paris, Islamabad and other cities around the world have been protesting against the Israeli attacks on Gaza
headline: Gaza violence sparks global protests - in pictures

standfirst: The Israeli military is on high alert in the West Bank, which has declared a 'day of rage' over the crisis in Gaza
headline: Gaza violence spreads to West Bank with six Palestinians reportedly killed

standfirst: As the death toll in Gaza passes 500, UN chief Ban Ki-moon calls on Israel to 'exercise maximum restraint' and spare civilian lives. Israeli continues to shell Gaza from the air and the ground on Monday. Sunday was one of the bloodiest days in Gaza, with Israel targeting the eastern neighbourhood of Shujai'iya
headline: Gaza death toll soars as UN urges Israel restraint – video

standfirst: The train, believed to be carrying 282 bodies from the MH17 plane crash, arrives in government-held Kharkiv in Ukraine, where a crash investigation centre has been set up, after a 17-hour journey from the town of Torez in rebel-held territory. The bodies will be flown to the Netherlands
headline: Train carrying bodies from flight MH17 arrives in Kharkiv - video

standfirst: Moscow insists documents that show Russians armed the separatists who shot down Malaysia Airlines plane are forged
headline: MH17 crash: sanctions against Russia are illegal, ambassador claims

standfirst: The foreign secretary, Philip Hammond, says the EU must send a "very clear signal to Russia" that it cannot continue its support for separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine, while welcoming the beginning of the repatriation of many of the bodies of victims from flight MH17
headline: Flight MH17: Russia must be sent clear message, says Hammond - video

standfirst: Experts fear that evidence of how the Malaysia Airlines MH17 plane was brought down could be lost for ever as evidence disappears from the crash site
headline: MH17 crash site chaos - in pictures

standfirst: Australian foreign minister Julie Bishop welcomed the acceptance of a UN resolution condemning the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 and demanding access to the crash site. Russia backed the resolution, but soon after accused Ukraine of exploiting the situation for political means
headline: MH17: UN resolution passes as Russia points fingers at Ukraine – video
Northern Ireland's lessons for Ukraine

standfirst: The UN secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, speaks in Israel about the bloody conflict in Gaza. President Shimon Peres says he regrets that flights into Tel Aviv have been cancelled, and says the solution should be to stop rockets being fired into the country by Hamas. Ban says he is encouraging dialogue between the two sides
headline: Ban Ki-moon and Shimon Peres on the Gaza/Israel crisis – video

standfirst: A UN-agreed halt to fighting between Israel and Hamas begins on Saturday morning. Israel's military says it will adhere to the ceasefire unless attacked, but would continue searching tunnels used by militants. Gaza's health ministry says 18 members of the same family were killed in the southern Gaza Strip just before the truce took hold
headline: Gaza and Israel begin 12-hour ceasefire - video

standfirst: US secretary of state arrives in Tel Aviv to meet political leaders in hopes of ending hostilities in Gaza
headline: John Kerry flies to Israel to push for ceasefire

standfirst: As a temporary 12-hour ceasefire comes into force in Gaza, Palestinians take to the ruined streets to survey the damage to their homes, find missing loved ones and locate scarce supplies
headline: Gaza ceasefire takes hold - in pictures

standfirst: Thousands of Gazans attempt to find shelter as the UN estimates that more than 100,000 are displaced
headline: Gazans flee Israeli bombardment – into the path of more bombs

standfirst: Wounded survivors flock to a hospital in Beit Lahiya after Israeli forces shelled a United Nations-run shelter in northern Gaza on Thursday. At least 15 people were killed in the shelling of the school where many Palestinians were taking shelter. As many as 200 people were injured in the attack
headline: Gaza hospital overwhelmed with survivors of Israeli strike on UN shelter - video

standfirst: Thousands of protesters have taken to the streets of Sydney in opposition to the Israeli ground invasion of Gaza. The Australian government has refrained from directly criticising Israel, instead censuring Hamas for refusing to accept an Egyptian-brokered ceasefire proposal. Protesters decried Israel as a 'terrorist state' while a number shouted 'God is great' in Arabic
headline: Thousands protest in Sydney over Israel ground invasion of Gaza - video

standfirst: Flights coming into Ben Gurion airport, Israel, from the US have been banned as rockets fired by Hamas pose increasing danger. Some European carriers have also stopped their flights, leaving many passengers stranded. One Hamas rocket hit a town on the fringes of the airport
headline: Israel: flight ban causes disruption at Ben Gurion airport - video

standfirst: Binyamin Netanyahu's ministers and Hamas turn down plan, though 12-hour 'pause' agreed for Saturday
headline: John Kerry fails to secure Gaza ceasefire as efforts for truce continue

standfirst: The US president says he has 'serious concerns' over the rising number of deaths on both sides of recent violence between Israel and Gaza. Barack Obama claims that while he supports Israel's right to defend itself against rockets fired by Hamas, he is hopeful the two sides can reach a ceasefire agreement. US Secretary of State John Kerry is on his way to the Middle East to facilitate talks between the two sides
headline: Barack Obama: we are focused on Israel-Gaza ceasefire - video
Lack of empathy with the Palestinians' plight

standfirst:
• Israeli soldier captured during intense battle in Shujai'iya
• Palestinian death toll nears 600, with 27 Israeli soldiers killed
• John Kerry to meet UN chief and Egyptian mediators in Cairo

Follow all the live developments here
headline: Israel hits hundreds of targets in Gaza as soldier is confirmed missing

standfirst: Israel air strikes continued to pummel Gaza overnight. Shells turned the night sky orange as they exploded. One woman in the town of Khan Younis in southern Gaza claimed residents were given no warning before the missiles landed: 'The children were screaming,' she said. On Monday an Israeli tank shell hit the al-Aqsa hospital in the central Gaza Strip
headline: 'The children were screaming': Israeli air strikes continue in Gaza - video
Academics call for a ceasefire and just peace agreement

standfirst: Thousands of Palestinians have demonstrated against Israel's assault on Gaza, where the death toll has topped 760, with most of those killed civilians and many of them children
headline: West Bank erupts in protest over Gaza onslaught - video
Setting the agenda in coverage of Gaza and MH17
